docstring.long_description:
**Compatibility:**
Compatible with National Instruments devices that utilize NI-DAQmx. Tested with a simulated NI-9234 module.

This block is designed for use with Windows and Linux systems due to NI driver availability. Ensure you have installed the NI-DAQmx runtime from https://www.ni.com/en/support/downloads/drivers/download.ni-daq-mx.html.
docstring.short_description: Creates a task with channel(s) to measure acceleration using an accelerometer.

parameters.name: cDAQ_start_channel
parameters.description: The device and channel to read from.

parameters.name: cDAQ_end_channel
parameters.description: To read from only one channel, set this to the same as `cDAQ_start_channel`. To read from multiple channels, set this to the last channel you want to read from.

parameters.name: min_val
parameters.description: Specifies in **units** the minimum value you expect to measure (default is -5.0).

parameters.name: max_val
parameters.description: Specifies in **units** the maximum value you expect to measure (default is 5.0).

parameters.name: units
parameters.description: The units to use to return accelerometer measurements (default is "G").

parameters.name: sensitivity
parameters.description: The sensitivity of the sensor. This value is in the units you specify with the `sensitivity_units` input. Refer to the sensor documentation to determine this value (default is 1000.0).

parameters.name: sensitivity_units
parameters.description: Specifies the units of the sensitivity input (default is "Millivolts per G").

parameters.name: current_excitation_source
parameters.description: Specifies the source of excitation (default is "Internal").

parameters.name: current_excitation_value
parameters.description: Specifies in amperes the amount of excitation to supply to the sensor. Refer to the sensor documentation to determine this value (default is 0.004).

returns.description: This block does not return any meaningful data; it is designed for creating a task to measure acceleration using an accelerometer.
